site.title: One Breath Partnership
site.description: One Breath Partnership elevates the work for clean air, every day, in Houston, Harris County and Texas.

mainImage.alt: It's time for the promises of Houston to work for everyone. Photo: One Breath Partnership.
mainImage.caption: It's time for the promises of Houston to work for everyone. Photo: One Breath Partnership.

node.title: Watch: This is our shared home

children.text: It's time for the promises of Houston to work for everyone — and that starts with actions that respect our shared home.

node.Action1Title: Share this story on social media with the hashtag #OurSharedHou

mainImage.alt: Benzene is one of the most commonly produced and most toxic chemicals in the U.S. Photo: Stephanie Young Merzel.
mainImage.caption: Benzene is one of the most commonly produced and most toxic chemicals in the U.S. Photo: Stephanie Young Merzel.

node.title: What is benzene?

children.text: Benzene is one of the most toxic chemicals in the U.S., and nowhere produces more of it than Texas.

node.Action1Title: Read the Center for Public Integrity's report on industry's denials of the risks of benzene

mainImage.alt: Houston's communities of color and lower wealth have often been forced to live in harm's way. Photo: Julie Demansky.
mainImage.caption: Houston's communities of color and lower wealth have often been forced to live in harm's way. Photo: Julie Demansky.

node.title: Houstonians don't have to live with pollution

children.text: We don’t have to accept that, when it comes to chemical disasters and industrial pollution in our communities, that whatever happens, happens.

node.Action1Title: Watch Air Alliance Houston's Dr. Bakeyah Nelson urge Congress to hold polluters accountable

mainImage.alt: There’s no evidence that TCEQ took any air quality measurements during Hurricane Harvey. Photo: Jill Carson.
mainImage.caption: There’s no evidence that TCEQ took any air quality measurements during Hurricane Harvey. Photo: Jill Carson.

node.title: TCEQ makes many questionable decisions. Here are some of the worst.

children.text: Texans deserve better from the agency charged with protecting our health and environment.

node.Action1Title: Join hundreds of Texans and sign the petition to #CleanUpTCEQ

mainImage.alt: Wally the Wise Guy teaches young people how to shelter in place during chemical disasters, such as the March 2019 fire at Intercontinental Terminals Company in Deer Park, Texas.
mainImage.caption: Wally the Wise Guy teaches young people how to shelter in place during chemical disasters, such as the March 2019 fire at Intercontinental Terminals Company in Deer Park, Texas.

node.title: The face of the petrochemical industry's recklessness

children.text: Like other safety mascots, Wally Wise Guy stands in for real solutions to protecting our health and preventing chemical disasters, showing us only how to live with them until they're over.

node.Action1Title: Learn more about Gov. Greg Abbott's history of siding with industry

mainImage.alt: A fire at Intercontinental Terminals Company in Deer Park raged for days. Photo: Mark Nguyen.
mainImage.caption: A fire at Intercontinental Terminals Company in Deer Park raged for days. Photo: Mark Nguyen.

node.title: What did Texas do about Houston's rash of chemical fires? Not much.

children.text: You might think three chemical fires in two weeks would prompt urgent bipartisan action in Austin, but that was not the case.

node.Action1Title: See how the chemical fires affected one Houston-area student

mainImage.alt: With action and change, the quality of life of Fifth Ward residents can improve.
mainImage.caption: With action and change, the quality of life of Fifth Ward residents can improve.

node.title: 'Change must come from within the community'

children.text: “Change must come from within the community, and that begins by holding those individuals that we elect accountable," said Rev. James Caldwell.

node.Action1Title: Share this video on social media with the hashtag #OurSharedHou

mainImage.alt: Texas regulators have not placed an air monitor in Pleasantville to document the impacts of the pollution sources.
mainImage.caption: Texas regulators have not placed an air monitor in Pleasantville to document the impacts of the pollution sources.

node.title: Community-led air monitoring in Pleasantville

children.text: Environmental Defense Fund has launched a project with Houston-based nonprofit Achieving Community Tasks Successfully (ACTS) and Texas Southern University to bring community-led air monitoring to a neighborhood surrounded by several pollution sources.

node.Action1Title: Learn more about the history of Pleasantville

mainImage.alt: One Breath Partnership in the media.
mainImage.caption: One Breath Partnership in the media.

node.title: We have to clean up the way we get around Houston

children.text: Because Houston can’t prosper without clean air, we must clean up the way we get around. Doubling down on costly car-centric infrastructure isn't it.

node.Action1Title: Share this story on social media with the hashtag #OurSharedHou

node.title: Federal report suggests 'negligence' worsened ITC fire

children.text: Investigating the dayslong fire, the U.S. Chemical Safety Board has found that the tank farm lacked a "remote emergency shutoff valve" and an alarm to alert workers.

node.Action1Title: Add your name to those who want to protect our shared home

node.title: There's more particulate matter in our air. And it's costing people their lives.

children.text: Researchers have found that particulate matter (PM 2.5) is getting worse and leading to an increase in preventable deaths.

node.Action1Title: Share this story on social media with the hashtag #OurSharedHou

mainImage.alt: One Breath Partnership in the media.
mainImage.caption: One Breath Partnership in the media.

node.title: Imelda led to unauthorized releases of benzene and other toxic pollutants

children.text: About 81,000 pounds of pollutants were released into the air without authorization during Tropical Storm Imelda.

node.Action1Title: Share the story on social media with the hashtag #OurSharedHou

mainImage.alt: One Breath Partnership in the media.
mainImage.caption: One Breath Partnership in the media.

node.title: TCEQ invests in better air monitoring equipment for Houston

children.text: After scrutiny about its ability to monitor Houston's air quality in real time, the TCEQ will invest $1.5 million on new equipment and technology.

node.Action1Title: Share this story on social media with the hashtag #OurSharedHou
